Steps for Beginners: 1. Lie flat on bench, eyes under bar 2. Grip bar slightly wider than shoulders 3. Unrack and lower to mid-chest 4. Press to lockout 5. Maintain 5-point contact
Advanced Key Points: 1. Retract scapulae throughout 2. Leg drive initiates press 3. Bar path slightly diagonal 4. Maintain wrist alignment 5. Control eccentric 2-3 sec
Scientific Reference: Lehman GJ (2005). The influence of grip width and forearm pronation/supination on upper-body myoelectric activity. J Strength Cond Res 19(3):587-591

Secondary Muscles: Anterior Deltoid, Triceps Brachii, Serratus Anterior
Steps for Beginners: 1. Set bench to 30-45 degrees 2. Start with dumbbells at shoulder height 3. Press up and slightly together 4. Lower with control to stretch 5. Avoid excessive arch
Advanced Key Points: 1. Greater ROM than barbell 2. Converge at top (slight medial rotation) 3. Elbows 45° from torso 4. Maintain shoulder depression 5. Unilateral stabilization demands
Scientific Reference: Barnett C et al. (1995). Effects of variations of the bench press exercise on the EMG activity of five shoulder muscles. J Strength Cond Res 9(4):222-227

Steps for Beginners: 1. Grip bars shoulder-width 2. Lean forward 20-30° 3. Lower until stretch felt 4. Press up maintaining lean 5. Avoid shoulder impingement
Advanced Key Points: 1. Forward lean activates chest 2. Elbows flared 45° 3. Full ROM crucial 4. Scapular protraction at top 5. Control descent 3 sec
Scientific Reference: Gołaś A et al. (2017). Optimizing half squat postactivation potentiation with handheld loading. J Strength Cond Res 31(11):3033-3038

Steps for Beginners: 1. Set cables at shoulder height 2. Step forward, slight bend 3. Bring hands together 4. Squeeze at midline 5. Return with control
Advanced Key Points: 1. Constant tension advantage 2. Hands cross over midline 3. Slight internal rotation 4. Maintain posture/avoid leaning 5. Peak contraction hold 1-2 sec
Scientific Reference: Welsch EA et al. (2005). Electromyographic activity of the pectoralis major and anterior deltoid muscles during three upper-body lifts. J Strength Cond Res 19(2):449-452

Steps for Beginners: 1. Hands shoulder-width 2. Body straight line 3. Lower chest to floor 4. Press to full extension 5. Engage core throughout
Advanced Key Points: 1. Scapular protraction crucial 2. Hollow body position 3. Hands under shoulders 4. Full ROM essential 5. Tempo control (2-0-2)
Scientific Reference: Freeman S et al. (2006). Quantifying muscle patterns and spine load during various forms of the push-up. Med Sci Sports Exerc 38(3):570-577

Steps for Beginners: 1. Secure feet in decline bench 2. Unrack with spotter 3. Lower to lower chest 4. Press to lockout 5. Controlled tempo
Advanced Key Points: 1. Emphasizes lower pec fibers 2. Shorter ROM than flat 3. Reduced shoulder stress 4. Higher loads possible 5. Avoid excessive decline
Scientific Reference: Glass SC, Armstrong T (1997). Electromyographical activity of the pectoralis muscle during incline and decline bench presses. J Strength Cond Res 11(3):163-167

Steps for Beginners: 1. Start with dumbbells pressed up 2. Slight elbow bend (fixed) 3. Arc out to sides 4. Deep stretch position 5. Return same arc path
Advanced Key Points: 1. Fixed elbow angle throughout 2. Eccentric 3-4 sec critical 3. Stretch emphasis exercise 4. Lighter loads required 5. Avoid going too deep
Scientific Reference: Welsch EA et al. (2005). EMG activity of pectoralis major during upper-body lifts. J Strength Cond Res 19(2):449-452

Steps for Beginners: 1. Set bench to 30-45 degrees 2. Wide overhand grip 3. Unrack with spotter 4. Lower to upper chest 5. Press to lockout
Advanced Key Points: 1. 44° incline optimal for clavicular head 2. Targets upper chest fibers 3. Grip slightly wider than flat bench 4. Maintain scapular retraction 5. Controlled eccentric essential
Scientific Reference: Barnett C et al. (1995). Effects of bench press variations on EMG. J Strength Cond Res 9(4):222-227

Steps for Beginners: 1. Adjust seat height (handles at chest) 2. Grip handles 3. Press until arms extended 4. Control return to start 5. Avoid locking elbows
Advanced Key Points: 1. Fixed movement path 2. Reduced stabilizer demand 3. Safe for beginners 4. Consistent tension on chest 5. Can load heavier safely
Scientific Reference: Schoenfeld BJ et al. (2010). Mechanisms of muscle hypertrophy. J Strength Cond Res 24(10):2857-2872

Steps for Beginners: 1. Adjust seat height (arms level) 2. Place forearms on pads 3. Bring arms together 4. Squeeze at midline 5. Return with control
Advanced Key Points: 1. Fixed movement path 2. Reduced stabilizer demand 3. Easy to reach failure safely 4. Consistent tension 5. Ideal for burnout sets
Scientific Reference: Welsch EA et al. (2005). EMG activity during chest exercises. J Strength Cond Res 19(2):449-452

Steps for Beginners: 1. Feet hip-width, bar over mid-foot 2. Hip hinge, grip bar 3. Chest up, neutral spine 4. Drive through floor 5. Lockout hips and knees
Advanced Key Points: 1. Maintain neutral spine throughout 2. Lats engaged (bend bar cue) 3. Bar path vertical 4. Hip hinge pattern crucial 5. Proper bracing essential
Scientific Reference: Swinton PA et al. (2011). A biomechanical analysis of straight and hexagonal barbell deadlifts. J Strength Cond Res 25(7):2000-2009

Secondary Muscles: Biceps Brachii, Lower Trapezius, Rhomboids, Posterior Deltoid
Steps for Beginners: 1. Grip bar wider than shoulders 2. Hang with arms extended 3. Pull chest to bar 4. Squeeze scapulae 5. Lower with control
Advanced Key Points: 1. Initiate with scapular depression 2. Lead with chest, not chin 3. Full ROM essential 4. Avoid kipping 5. Dead hang each rep
Scientific Reference: Youdas JW et al. (2010). Surface EMG comparison during pull-up variations. J Strength Cond Res 24(7):1941-1949

Steps for Beginners: 1. Hip hinge 45° forward 2. Grip shoulder-width or wider 3. Row to lower ribcage 4. Squeeze scapulae 5. Lower with control
Advanced Key Points: 1. Maintain hip hinge position 2. Horizontal pull emphasis 3. Elbow path crucial 4. Avoid excessive momentum 5. Retract and depress scapulae
Scientific Reference: Fenwick CM et al. (2009). Comparison of different rowing exercises. Med Sci Sports Exerc 41(5):1265-1270

Steps for Beginners: 1. Secure thighs under pad 2. Grip bar wider than shoulders 3. Pull to upper chest 4. Lean back slightly (15°) 5. Control ascent
Advanced Key Points: 1. Initiate with scapular depression 2. Pull to clavicles, not waist 3. Elbows down and back 4. Avoid excessive lean 5. Squeeze lats at bottom
Scientific Reference: Andersen V et al. (2014). Muscle activation during pull-up variations. J Strength Cond Res 28(4):1135-1142

Steps for Beginners: 1. Sit with feet on platform 2. Grip handle, slight knee bend 3. Row to abdomen 4. Squeeze scapulae together 5. Extend arms fully
Advanced Key Points: 1. Torso upright throughout 2. Drive elbows back 3. Scapular retraction emphasis 4. Avoid excessive trunk movement 5. Full stretch at extension
Scientific Reference: Fenwick CM et al. (2009). EMG comparison of rowing exercises. Med Sci Sports Exerc 41(5):1265-1270

Steps for Beginners: 1. Hand and knee on bench 2. Dumbbell in opposite hand 3. Row to hip/ribcage 4. Squeeze at top 5. Lower with control
Advanced Key Points: 1. Unilateral anti-rotation demand 2. Greater ROM than barbell 3. Avoid trunk rotation 4. Pull to hip, not shoulder 5. Maintain neutral spine
Scientific Reference: Lehman GJ et al. (2004). Muscle recruitment patterns during the prone row. J Strength Cond Res 18(4):804-808

Steps for Beginners: 1. Straddle bar, hip hinge 2. Grip handles 3. Row to chest/abdomen 4. Squeeze scapulae 5. Lower to full extension
Advanced Key Points: 1. Neutral grip reduces bicep involvement 2. Thick back development 3. Heavy loading possible 4. Maintain hip hinge 5. Stable base crucial
Scientific Reference: Fenwick CM et al. (2009). EMG analysis of rowing variations. Med Sci Sports Exerc 41(5):1265-1270

Steps for Beginners: 1. Grip bar shoulder-width, palms facing 2. Hang at full extension 3. Pull chest to bar 4. Squeeze back muscles 5. Lower 3 seconds
Advanced Key Points: 1. Greater bicep activation vs pull-ups 2. Slightly easier than pull-ups 3. Full ROM critical 4. Scapular mechanics key 5. Avoid momentum
Scientific Reference: Youdas JW et al. (2010). EMG of pull-up variations. J Strength Cond Res 24(7):1941-1949

Steps for Beginners: 1. Set cable at upper height 2. Grip rope, thumbs to chest 3. Pull to face level 4. External rotation at end 5. Squeeze scapulae
Advanced Key Points: 1. Shoulder health exercise 2. External rotation crucial 3. High rep ranges effective 4. Pull apart at finish 5. Retraction emphasis
Scientific Reference: Schoenfeld BJ et al. (2013). Effects of varied resistance training protocols. J Strength Cond Res 27(8):2240-2249

Steps for Beginners: 1. Grip bar, body under it 2. Body straight, heels on ground 3. Pull chest to bar 4. Squeeze scapulae 5. Lower with control
Advanced Key Points: 1. Scalable by bar height 2. Scapular mechanics identical 3. Core engagement throughout 4. Regression for pull-ups 5. High rep capacity
Scientific Reference: Contreras B et al. (2013). Comparison of upper body exercises. J Strength Cond Res 27(5):1302-1309

Secondary Muscles: Triceps, Upper Trapezius, Serratus Anterior, Upper Pectoralis

Advanced Key Points: 1. Full overhead lockout essential 2. Avoid excessive low back arch 3. Squeeze glutes for stability 4. Bar path around face 5. Greater stabilizer demand than dumbbell
Scientific Reference: Saeterbakken AH et al. (2013). Effects of body position and loading modality on muscle activity during shoulder exercises. J Strength Cond Res 27(7):1824-1831

Steps for Beginners: 1. Stand with dumbbells at sides 2. Slight forward lean 3. Raise to shoulder height 4. Slight bend in elbows 5. Lower with control
Advanced Key Points: 1. Neutral or internal rotation thumb position 2. Control eccentric 3 sec 3. Stop at shoulder height 4. Avoid momentum/swinging 5. Scapular stability crucial
Scientific Reference: Campos YAC et al. (2020). Different shoulder exercises and EMG activity. J Hum Kinet 75:5-14

Steps for Beginners: 1. Sit with back support 2. Dumbbells at shoulder height 3. Press overhead 4. Lock out at top 5. Lower to shoulders
Advanced Key Points: 1. Greater ROM than barbell 2. Independent arm movement 3. Reduced stability demand 4. Converge slightly at top 5. Controlled tempo (2-0-2-1)
Scientific Reference: Saeterbakken AH et al. (2013). Muscle activity during shoulder press variations. J Strength Cond Res 27(7):1824-1831

Steps for Beginners: 1. Cable at low position, opposite hand 2. Stand perpendicular to machine 3. Raise across body to shoulder height 4. Control descent 5. Repeat other side
Advanced Key Points: 1. Constant tension advantage 2. Unilateral focus 3. Reduced momentum capability 4. Peak contraction at top 5. Smooth arc motion
Scientific Reference: Schoenfeld BJ et al. (2010). Mechanisms of muscle hypertrophy. J Strength Cond Res 24(10):2857-2872

Steps for Beginners: 1. Start palms facing, dumbbells at chin 2. Press and rotate to neutral 3. Full overhead lockout 4. Reverse rotation descending 5. Return to start position
Advanced Key Points: 1. Rotation engages multiple angles 2. Greater anterior delt activation 3. Continuous tension 4. Requires shoulder mobility 5. Moderate loads recommended
Scientific Reference: Paoli A et al. (2010). Effect of different variations on muscle activation. J Sports Med Phys Fitness 50(3):319-323

Secondary Muscles: Medial Deltoid, Clavicular Pectoralis, Serratus Anterior
Steps for Beginners: 1. Stand with weights at thighs 2. Raise to eye level 3. Slight bend in elbows 4. Control descent 5. Alternate or both arms
Advanced Key Points: 1. Stop at shoulder/eye level 2. Avoid momentum 3. Eccentric control crucial 4. Neutral or pronated grip 5. Often redundant with pressing
Scientific Reference: Campos YAC et al. (2020). EMG activity in shoulder exercises. J Hum Kinet 75:5-14

Steps for Beginners: 1. Face machine, chest on pad 2. Grip handles 3. Fly outward to horizontal 4. Squeeze scapulae 5. Return with control

Scientific Reference: Schoenfeld BJ et al. (2013). Muscle activation patterns. J Strength Cond Res 27(8):2240-2249

Scientific Reference: Borreani S et al. (2015). Muscle activation during push-up variations. J Strength Cond Res 29(1):265-275

Advanced Key Points: 1. Shoulder-friendly pressing angle 2. Anti-rotation core demand 3. Unilateral instability 4. Natural arc motion 5. Excellent for shoulder health
Scientific Reference: Calatayud J et al. (2016). Muscle activity levels in shoulder exercises. Sports Biomech 15(1):42-53

Steps for Beginners: 1. Cable at face height 2. Pull rope to face 3. Externally rotate at end 4. Hands beside ears 5. Control return
Advanced Key Points: 1. Critical for shoulder health 2. External rotation component key 3. High volume tolerated 4. Scapular retraction emphasis 5. Pull apart rope at finish
Scientific Reference: Schoenfeld BJ et al. (2013). Training protocols and muscle activation. J Strength Cond Res 27(8):2240-2249

Scientific Reference: Marcolin G et al. (2018). EMG analysis of biceps exercises. Eur J Appl Physiol 118(2):371-380

Steps for Beginners: 1. Stand with dumbbells at sides 2. Neutral grip (palms facing) 3. Curl to shoulders 4. Squeeze at top 5. Lower with control
Advanced Key Points: 1. Neutral grip emphasizes brachialis 2. Builds arm thickness 3. Easier on wrists 4. Can alternate or simultaneous 5. Forearm development
Scientific Reference: Boeckh-Behrens WU, Buskies W (2000). Fitness Strength Training: The Best Exercises and Methods for Sport and Health. Rowohlt Taschenbuch Verlag

Advanced Key Points: 1. Eliminates momentum completely 2. Constant tension on biceps 3. Short head emphasis 4. Full stretch at bottom 5. Controlled eccentric critical
Scientific Reference: Oliveira LF et al. (2009). EMG activity of biceps during curl variations. J Strength Cond Res 23(7):2045-2050

Steps for Beginners: 1. Stand facing cable machine 2. Grip bar, arms extended 3. Curl to shoulders 4. Squeeze biceps 5. Control descent
Advanced Key Points: 1. Constant tension throughout 2. Adjustable resistance curve 3. Bilateral or unilateral 4. Excellent pump effect 5. Reduced cheating capability
Scientific Reference: Boeckh-Behrens WU, Buskies W (2000). Strength training exercise analysis. Rowohlt Taschenbuch Verlag

Advanced Key Points: 1. Maximum isolation possible 2. Minimal momentum 3. Strong mind-muscle connection 4. Unilateral focus 5. Short head activation
Scientific Reference: Oliveira LF et al. (2009). EMG comparison of curl exercises. J Strength Cond Res 23(7):2045-2050

Steps for Beginners: 1. Supinated grip shoulder-width 2. Hang at full extension 3. Pull chest to bar 4. Squeeze biceps at top 5. Lower 3 seconds
Advanced Key Points: 1. Compound arm builder 2. Heavy load on biceps 3. Full body tension 4. Supinated grip crucial 5. Dead hang each rep
Scientific Reference: Youdas JW et al. (2010). EMG during pull-up variations. J Strength Cond Res 24(7):1941-1949

Steps for Beginners: 1. Sit on incline bench 2. Arms hanging perpendicular to floor 3. Curl alternating or together 4. Squeeze at top 5. Lower to full extension
Advanced Key Points: 1. Maximizes bicep stretch 2. Long head emphasis 3. Reduced momentum capability 4. Greater ROM 5. Supination throughout
Scientific Reference: Marcolin G et al. (2018). EMG of biceps curl variations. Eur J Appl Physiol 118(2):371-380

Advanced Key Points: 1. Constant tension on brachialis 2. Can pull rope apart at top 3. Neutral grip maintained 4. Excellent brachialis builder 5. Smooth resistance curve
Scientific Reference: Boeckh-Behrens WU, Buskies W (2000). Exercise analysis for strength training. Rowohlt Taschenbuch Verlag

Advanced Key Points: 1. Eliminates all momentum 2. Constant tension 3. Short head emphasis 4. Peak contraction focused 5. Arms perpendicular to floor
Scientific Reference: Oliveira LF et al. (2009). EMG activity in biceps exercises. J Strength Cond Res 23(7):2045-2050

Steps for Beginners: 1. Stand with pronated grip 2. Barbell at thighs 3. Curl to shoulders 4. Squeeze forearms 5. Lower with control

Advanced Key Points: 1. Long head maximal stretch 2. Elbow position fixed 3. Overhead position crucial 4. Full ROM essential 5. Controlled eccentric
Scientific Reference: Boeckh-Behrens WU, Buskies W (2000). Fitness strength training exercises. Rowohlt Taschenbuch Verlag

Advanced Key Points: 1. Upright torso = tricep focus 2. Heavy loading possible 3. Full ROM essential 4. Can add weight belt 5. Mass builder exercise

Advanced Key Points: 1. Upper arms perpendicular to floor 2. Elbows stay fixed 3. Can lower past forehead 4. Moderate weights safer 5. Long head stretch
Scientific Reference: Boeckh-Behrens WU, Buskies W (2000). Strength training methods. Rowohlt Taschenbuch Verlag

Steps for Beginners: 1. Face cable machine 2. Grip rope ends 3. Push down and apart 4. Full extension with split 5. Control return
Advanced Key Points: 1. Pull rope apart at bottom 2. Lateral head emphasis 3. Full elbow extension 4. Elbows stationary 5. Squeeze contraction
Scientific Reference: Boeckh-Behrens WU, Buskies W (2000). Strength training analysis. Rowohlt Taschenbuch Verlag

Steps for Beginners: 1. Bar on front delts, fingers under bar 2. Elbows high 3. Descend upright 4. Drive through full foot 5. Maintain torso position
Advanced Key Points: 1. More upright than back squat 2. Greater quad emphasis 3. Reduced spinal loading 4. Mobility demanding 5. Core stability crucial
Scientific Reference: Gullett JC et al. (2009). Biomechanical comparison of back and front squats. J Strength Cond Res 23(1):284-292

Advanced Key Points: 1. Foot position alters emphasis 2. High foot = glutes, low = quads 3. Back stays on pad 4. Full ROM beneficial 5. Heavy loading safe

Advanced Key Points: 1. Teaching tool for squat pattern 2. Promotes upright torso 3. Hip mobility developer 4. Counter-balance effect 5. Beginner friendly

Advanced Key Points: 1. Fixed movement path 2. Excellent quad builder 3. Reduced stability demand 4. Safe for heavy loads 5. Foot position variations
Scientific Reference: Escamilla RF et al. (2001). Machine exercise biomechanics. Med Sci Sports Exerc 33(1):127-141

Scientific Reference: McAllister MJ et al. (2014). Muscle activation during deadlift variations. J Strength Cond Res 28(7):1909-1918

Steps for Beginners: 1. Upper back on bench 2. Bar over hips (padded) 3. Feet flat, shoulder-width 4. Thrust hips up to parallel 5. Squeeze glutes at top
Advanced Key Points: 1. Peak glute activation exercise 2. Full hip extension crucial 3. Posterior pelvic tilt at top 4. Hold contraction 2 sec 5. Heavy loads tolerated
Scientific Reference: Contreras B et al. (2015). EMG comparison of gluteal exercises. J Strength Cond Res 29(4):1056-1066

Advanced Key Points: 1. Eccentric hamstring emphasis 2. Injury prevention benefits 3. Extremely challenging 4. Band assistance for beginners 5. Control descent 5+ sec
Scientific Reference: Mjølsnes R et al. (2004). 10-week Nordic hamstring study. Am J Sports Med 32(6):1459-1467

Advanced Key Points: 1. True hamstring isolation 2. Full ROM essential 3. Hips stay on pad 4. Controlled eccentric 3 sec 5. Point toes for calf reduction
Scientific Reference: Wright GA et al. (1999). EMG of hamstring exercises. J Strength Cond Res 13(4):370-375

Steps for Beginners: 1. Face away from cable 2. Rope between legs 3. Hip hinge forward 4. Drive hips through 5. Squeeze glutes at finish
